subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit vs. Agitator
msgSnippet: ... Agitator can help identify technical loss--it can t do that on its own. Understood. -- J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info Your guide to
messageBody:
Jeffrey Fredrick wrote:
> On 5/30/06, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:

> > TDD practitioners are good at identifying technical value (clean code
> > that does the right thing with the right input) and JUnit is a key tool
> > for that purpose. Agitator can help identify technical loss: boundary
> > cases that might be of interest to the programmer and might represent
> > technical holes other modules can exploit to hurt the system. This is
> > how I imagine using Agitator in my practice.
> >
> > How does that sound?
>
> I think that's headed the right direction but I wouldn't want to give
> undue credit to the tool here: the Agitator might point out that a
> certain exception will happen but it can't make the judgement about if
> that is expected or if there is potential technical loss.
> Fundamentally it is the developer who is in control and who needs to
> supply that judgement; Agitator's role is to submit that behavior to
> the developer for judgement.

Agitator can help identify technical loss--it can't do that on its own.
Understood.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info
Your guide to software craftsmanship
JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
